sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Prior to and 30 minutes after intravitreal injection, evaluate intraocular pressure using tonometry.
  • Choroidal retinal neovascularization, Secondary to pathologic myopia: 0.5 mg/0.05 mL INTRAVITREAL injection and monthly dosing as needed (study dose)
  • Diabetic macular edema: 0.3 mg (0.05 mL of 6 mg/mL ranibizumab solution) INTRAVITREALLY once monthly (approximately 28 days); give adequate anesthesia and a broad-spectrum microbicide prior to injection
  • Diabetic macular edema - Diabetic retinopathy: 0.3 mg (0.05 mL of 6 mg/mL ranibizumab solution) INTRAVITREALLY once monthly (approximately 28 days); give adequate anesthesia and a broad-spectrum microbicide prior to injection
  • Exudative age-related macular degeneration: 0.5 mg (0.05 mL of 10 mg/mL ranibizumab solution) by INTRAVITREAL injection once a month (approximately 28 days); give adequate anesthesia and a broad-spectrum microbicide prior to injection
  • Exudative age-related macular degeneration: alternative dosing: may reduce to 0.5 mg by INTRAVITREAL injection every 3 months after the first 4 monthly injections if monthly injections are not feasible; dose will be less effective, leading to an approximate 5-letter (1-line) average loss of visual acuity over the following 9 months OR may reduce to 0.5 mg by INTRAVITREAL injection monthly for 3 months followed by less frequent injections (average 4 to 5 injections over 9 months) if monthly injections are not feasible; dose will be less effective, leading to a maintenance of visual acuity compared with a 1- to 2-letter gain with monthly injections; give adequate anesthesia and a broad-spectrum microbicide prior to injection
  • Macular retinal edema - Thrombosis of retinal vein: 0.5 mg (0.05 mL of 10 mg/mL ranibizumab solution) by INTRAVITREAL injection once a month (approximately 28 days); give adequate anesthesia and a broad-spectrum microbicide prior to injection

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Diabetic macular edema
  • Diabetic macular edema - Diabetic retinopathy
  • Exudative age-related macular degeneration
  • Macular retinal edema - Thrombosis of retinal vein
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Choroidal retinal neovascularization, Secondary to pathologic myopia

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to ranibizumab or any component of the product; reactions may manifest as severe intraocular inflammation
  • infection, ocular or periocular

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• arterial thromboembolic events (nonfatal stroke, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or vascular death) have occurred
  • endophthalmitis has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • intraocular pressure increase has been observed within 60 minutes of injection; monitoring recommended
  • retinal detachment has occurred
  • report suspected adverse events to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Ophthalmic:Cataract (2% to 17%), Conjunctival hemorrhage (47% to 74%), Eye irritation (7% to 15%), Foreign body sensation, in the eyes (7% to 16%), Inflammatory disorder of the eye (4% to 18%), Pain in eye (17% to 35%), Raised intraocular pressure (7% to 24%), Visual disturbance (5% to 18%), Vitreous detachment (4% to 21%), Vitreous floaters (7% to 27%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Arterial thromboembolism (0.8% to 10.8%), Atrial fibrillation (1% to 5%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident (0.2% to 4.8%)
  • Ophthalmic:Atrophic iris (2%), Central retinal vein occlusion - ischemic, Endophthalmitis (1.9%), Glaucoma (2%), Iridocyclitis (52.9% to 73.6%), Retinal detachment, Retinal hemorrhage (3.9% to 24.5%), Retinal tear (1.9%), Thrombosis of retinal artery (2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ranibizumab inhibits the human vascular endothelial growth factor A (VEGF-A) by binding to its active forms, thereby preventing ocular angiogenesis by VEGF-A including reduced endothelial cell proliferation, vascular leakage, and new blood vessel formation.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    For ophthalmic intravitreal injection only
  • Intravitreal
    • Use 1 vial per eye; change sterile field, gloves, drapes, eyelid speculum, filter, and injection needles before administration to the other eye
    • Withdraw the entire content (0.2 mL) of ranibizumab through a 5-micron, 19-gauge filter needle, switch to a 30-gauge x 0.5-inch needle and purge content to 0.05 mL before administering

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• maintenance or improvement in visual acuity indicates efficacy
  • intraocular pressure elevations; tonometry before and 30 minutes after injection
  • perfusion of optic nerve head; immediately after injection
  • signs and symptoms of endophthalmitis (redness, sensitivity to light, pain, vision changes); after injection
  • signs and symptoms of retinal detachment; after injection

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of endophthalmitis (eye pain or redness, sensitivity to light, or vision changes).
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of myocardial infarction or stroke.
  • Drug may cause conjunctival hemorrhage, increased intraocular pressure, eye pain, vitreous floaters, and intraocular inflammation.
